Problem:
Consider a system described by the partial differential equation \(\frac{\partial u}{\partial t} = Lu\), where \(L\) is a linear differential operator. An integral transform, specifically the Laplace transform, is applied to the system, represented by \( \mathcal{L}\{u(t)\} = U(s) \).

If an additional operator \( M \) is applied as an intervention at some \( t_1 \), modifying the system to \(\frac{\partial u}{\partial t} = Mu\) post \( t_1 \), will the resulting \( U(s) \) for \( s > s_1 \) depend solely on \( L \) and not on \( M \)?
Explanation: The intervention with the operator \( M \) alters the governing equation post \( t_1 \), thus changing the dynamic of \( u(t) \) and consequently affecting \( U(s) \). The resulting \( U(s) \) after intervention will reflect the influence of both \( L \) and \( M \), indicating a dependency on both operators.
